newsitem.title: USA: FCOJ futures close narrowly mixed, consolidate.
newsitem.headline: FCOJ futures close narrowly mixed, consolidate.

text.p: Frozen concentrated orange juice May futures fell barely below unchanged on the close after local and trade buying supported prices throughout the day, dealers said.
The front three months fell to new contract lows in early trade, but technically-driven buying pushed the market higher after prices failed to rack up additional losses.
May settled down 0.20 cent at 76.15 cents per lb, having ranged from 76.75 to 75.50 cents, a new contract low. The back months finished 0.05 lower to 0.05 firmer.
Support was seen at 74.00 and then at 72.00 cents in May.
Volume was estimated at 3,500 lots compared to Monday's official 6,513 lots.
Analysts said today's gains represent a temporary correction to recent losses, adding that prices should continue to fall amid abundant supplies.
"The market will be burdened with supplies for the next few years," an analyst said.
The Brazilian state of Sao Paulo said its orange crop could reach 381.8 million 40-kg boxes in 1997/98 compared to about 355 million boxes this year.
The Brazilian Association of Citrus Exporters will release its first estimate of Brazil's 1997/98 crop on May 20.
Also, Mexico said it will produce about 48,000 tonnes of orange juice concentrate in 1997, down from 50,000 tonnes in 1996. Most of the concentrate will be exported.
SNIM, a branch of the Mexican Trade Ministry, blamed the decline on a rise in demand for fresh orange juice following the country's economic recovery.
Industry sources expect the U.S. Department of Agriculture to raise Florida yields in its next report, released April 11.
"There is plenty of juice on the planet and there will be for a long time," the analyst said. "All we can do is wait for the technicals to become oversold."
Following today's close, the U.S. Department of Agriculture said Brazil's 1996 orange juice output would reach 1.14 million tonnes, compared to 1.06 million tonnes in its previous estimate.
Exports were estimated at 1.095 million tonnes versus 1.05 million tonnes previously.
